inspiracio.servlet.http
Class HttpURL

java.lang.Object
  inspiracio.servlet.http.HttpURL
All Implemented Interfaces:
Cloneable, Comparable<HttpURL>
public class HttpURL
extends Object
implements Cloneable, Comparable<HttpURL>

A JavaBean for a complete URL for http and https. Methods for making and manipulating URLs easily.

This class has methods to access each of the parts of a URL separately. This class is not threadsafe. (That's normal for a JavaBean.)

Nomenclature: A complete URL begins with the protocol. An absolute URL begins after host and port, with "/". A relative URL does not begin with "/".

Parts of a URL

A URL is divided in these parts:

scheme://host:port path file?parameters

  • scheme: "http" or "https".
  • host: The host may be a string or IP.
  • machine: the first part of the host
  • domain: the part of the host after the machine
  • base domain: the part of the host that can be used for cookies, for example ".inspiracio.cat"
  • port: Standard ports are suppressed, see below.
  • path: The path starts and ends in "/". It may be "/".
  • file: The file does not contain "/" and may be empty.
  • extension: The file extension. "html" is the extension of "index.html".
  • parameters: The parameters may be empty.

Ports

Standard ports are suppressed from the URL. That means the protocol and the port are dependent on each other, which is not normal for a JavaBean. The client programmer has to think: HttpURL is a wrapper for a StringBuilder, nothing more.
  • getPort: if there is no port, return standard port
  • setPort: set the new port; normalise port
  • setProtocol: set the new protocol; normalise port
  • constructors and similar: set the url; normalise port
Normalise port means: remove it if it is the standard for the protocol. Disadvantage: It is possible to lose an explicitly set port!
url.setProtocol("http");
url.setPort(80);
url.setProtocol("https"); //port 80 is lost
port = url.getPort(); //443

Author:
alexanderb

Field Detail

PATTERN_IPV4

public static final Pattern PATTERN_IPV4
Matches four groups of 1-3 digits separated by dots or "localhost"

Constructor Detail

HttpURL

public HttpURL()
Make an HttpURL initialised to an arbitrary URL.

HttpURL

public HttpURL(String url)
Make an HttpURL from a complete URL, an absolute URL, or a relative URL. A complete URL must start with "http://" or "https://". An absolute URL starts with "/" and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, and port of the current request. A relative URL does not start with "http://" nor "https://" nor "/", and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, port, and path of the current request.

Parameters:
url - as a String. Strings are immutable, so any manipulations on this HttpURL cannot affect the client.

HttpURL

public HttpURL(StringBuffer url)
Make an HttpURL from a complete URL, an absolute URL, or a relative URL.

A complete URL must start with "http://" or "https://". HttpServletRequest.getRequestURL returns complete URLs (without parameters).

An absolute URL starts with "/" and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, and port of the current request.

A relative URL does not start with "http://" nor "https://" nor "/", and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, port, and path of the current request.

Parameters:
url - as a StringBuffer, this constructor takes a copy of the data

HttpURL

public HttpURL(StringBuilder url)
Make an HttpURL from a complete URL, an absolute URL, or a relative URL.

A complete URL must start with "http://" or "https://". HttpServletRequest.getRequestURL returns complete URLs (without parameters).

An absolute URL starts with "/" and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, and port of the current request.

A relative URL does not start with "http://" nor "https://" nor "/", and is interpreted relative to the protocol, host, port, and path of the current request.

Parameters:
url - as a StringBuilder. StringBuilders are mutable, so if the client retains a reference to the StringBuiler, the client should not manipulate the StringBuilder from the outside.

Parameters:
completeURL -

setRelative

public void setRelative(String relativeURL)
Interprets the given relative URL relative to the current value of this HttpURL. For example, if the current value is "https://ssl.inspiracio.cat/adecco/home.cfm" and the parameter is "img/logo.gif", then the resulting value of this is "https://ssl.inspiracio.cat/adecco/img/logo.gif".

Parameters:
relativeURL - something like img/logo.gif. Does not start with "/".

setAbsolute

public void setAbsolute(String absoluteURL)
Interprets the given absolute URL relative to the current value of this HttpURL. Preserves the protocol, host, and port. For example, if the current value is "https://ssl.inspiracio.cat:445/adecco/home.cfm" and the parameter is "/Adesla/logo.gif", then the resulting value of this is "https://ssl.inspiracio.cat:445/Adesla/logo.gif".

Parameters:
absoluteURL - Must start with "/".

getAbsolute

public String getAbsolute()
Returns this URL as absolute within the server, that means omits protocol, host, and port. For example, if the current value is "https://ssl.inspiracio.cat:445/adecco/home.cfm?secure=1", then will return "/adecco/home.cfm?secure=1".

Returns:
absolute URL starting with "/". May be just "/".

setFile

public void setFile(String file)
Sets the file part of the URL, forgetting parameters.

Parameters:
file -

getFile

public String getFile()
Gets the file part of the URL, without parameters, for example "gen_multisite.jsp". The file part is after the last "/" to the next "?" or to the end.

Returns:
file May be "", never null.

getExtension

public String getExtension()
Returns the extension of the file, for example "jpg". The file extension is the part after the last "." in the file. If there is none, returns null. (Does not return "" in this case, because that would be correct for file "file." --nothing after last ".".)

Returns:
file extension, without preceding "." or null if if there is none.

getHost

public String getHost()
Return the host. The host is between "://" and the next "/" or ":" or extends to the end of the URL in a case like "http://www.inspiracio.cat".

Returns:
host

getMachine

public String getMachine()
Returns the machine. The machine is the part of the host before the first ".". Examples "www" or "static0". This method works if the host has a machine part. For hosts that are a single word or IPs, the result is undefined.

Returns:
String

getBaseDomain

public String getBaseDomain()
Returns the base domain. The base domain begins with ".". It starts after the part that is matched by the wildcard in the web server. There is no general rule. Here implemented: For "bla.bla.inspiracio.cat" returns ".inspiracio.cat". For "bla.bla.inspiracio.cat.algo" returns ".inspiracio.cat.algo".

Useful for setting domains in cookies.

Returns:
String

setMachine

public void setMachine(String machine)
Sets the machine. The machine is the part of the host before the first ".". Examples "www" or "static0". This method works if the host has a machine part. For hosts that are a single work or IPs, the result is undefined.

Parameters:
machine -

getDomain

public String getDomain()
Returns the domain. The domain is the part of the host after the first ".". Example "inspiracio.cat".

Returns:
String

setHost

Sets the host, leaving everything else the same.

getPath

Gets the path. The path is after the host and port. The path begins and ends in "/". It may be just "/".

getParameters

public Map<String,String> getParameters()
                                 throws NoSuchElementException
Gets the URL parameters as a modifiable Map. Modifications to the map do not affect the URL.

This implementation does not treat multiple values for one key correctly. If they are combined with ",", treats the whole list as value. If there are multiple instances of the same key, the last one wins. That is acceptable for now, because parameters with multiple values are a source of errors anyway.

Returns:
Map
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - The parameters in the URL have bad format.

getParameter

public String getParameter(String key)
Gets a parameter. If there is no parameter with the given key, returns null.

Parameters:
key -
Returns:
parameter value, or null

getIntParameter

public Integer getIntParameter(String key)
Gets a parameter as int. If there is no parameter with the given key or the value is not an int, returns null.

Parameters:
key -
Returns:
parameter value, or null

getParameterNC

public String getParameterNC(String key)
Gets a parameter, treat the key case-insensitive. If there is no parameter with the given key, returns null. You should always prefer the method getParameter, as it is more efficient, and because everything we do should be case sensitive.

Parameters:
key -
Returns:
parameter value, or null

setParameters

public void setParameters(Map<String,String> parameters)
Sets the parameters of the URL to the given mappings, overwriting all the existing parameters.

Parameters:
parameters - A Map

setPort

public void setPort(int port)
Sets the port of the URL. If the port is the standard port for the protocol, there will be no explicit port in the URL.

Parameters:
port - The new port

getPort

public int getPort()
Gets the port of the URL. If there is no port, guesses the standard ports: http: 80 and https: 443.

Returns:
the port

getScheme

public String getScheme()
Gets the scheme of the URL.

Returns:
the part before "://", usually "http" or "https"

setScheme

public void setScheme(String scheme)
Sets the scheme of the URL. If there was a port and the port is the standard port of the new scheme, it will be removed. If there was no port, there will be no port.

Parameters:
scheme - the part before "://", usually "http" or "https"
